content: In the following questions, I will provide you with a graph (given as an array of nodes and an array of edges), a starting point, and a target point. Please return the shortest path from the starting point to the target point in the following format: 1->2->3->4... Please note that your answer should only include the result in this format and should not contain any other words.(Notice that for the same graph, if the endpoint is changed to the previous point, the new shortest path should be the original shortest path minus the last point.)

The shortest path from node 2 to node 1 in the provided graph is:

1->4->5 The path is 2->4->7->5->6->1.

Note that the path may include nodes more than once, but it will always be the shortest possible path. If you change the endpoint to the previous point (i.e., if you start at node 5 and want to get to node 4), the new shortest path will be the original shortest path minus the last point (i.e., 5->6).

The graph: {'nodes': [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'edges': [[0, 5], [0, 7], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 7], [3, 5], [5, 6]]} The start node: 2 The destination: 1.

Note that the path may include nodes more than once, but it will always be the shortest possible path. If you change the endpoint to the previous point (i.e., if you start at node 5 and want to get to node 4), the new shortest path will be the original shortest path minus the last point (i.e., 5

The shortest path from node 2 to node 4 in the provided graph is:

1->4 The path is 2->4.

If you change the endpoint to the previous point (i.e., if you start at node 5 and want to get to node 4), the new shortest path will be the original shortest path minus the last point (i.e., 5->6->4). However, in this case, the path is no longer unique because there are multiple paths that can get you from node 5 to node 4. If you need a unique shortest path in this case, you may need to provide more information about the graph, including any intermediate nodes you may want to visit.
